occurrences.line_text: Which Coridon first hearing, ran in hast
His Loues deare spoile, in which his heart was prayde,
With which so sternely he the monster strooke,
Which he so wisely well did prosecute,
But fed on spoile and booty, which they made
Vpon their neighbours, which did nigh them border,
Amongst the rest, the which they then did pray,
Mongst which this lucklesse mayd away was lad,
Which was the conquest of the gentlest Knight,
Couered with shrubby woods, in which no way
For the thicke shrubs, which did them alwaies shade
But with continuall candlelight, which delt
To merchants, which them kept in bondage hard,
And pittifull complaints, which there she made,
And waste her goodly beauty, which did fade
Which may her feeble leaues with comfort glade.
Amongst those theeues, which her in bondage strong
That he, which was their Capitaine profest,
Of all the other pray, which they had got,
By which he mote accomplish his request,
Which gaue him hope, and did him halfe perswade,
A sodaine sickenesse, which her sore opprest,
During which space that she thus sicke did lie,
It chaunst a sort of merchants, which were wount
All which he to the marchants sale did showe.
Till some, which did the sundry prisoners knowe,
Which with the rest they tooke not long agoe,
With which none had to doe, ne ought partake,
But he himselfe, which did that conquest make;
Of carcases, which dying on her fell.
He mote perceiue by signes, which he did fynd,
First all the captiues, which they here had hent,
Of cryes and clamors, which amongst them past,
Which with those gentle shepherds here I wont to lead.
There did they find, that which they did not feare,
The selfe same flocks, the which those theeues had reft
The which for want of heards themselues then kept.
But when he saw the theeues, which did them keepe,
Mongst which the theeues them questioned againe,
That they were poore heardgroomes, the which whylere
With which he streight went to the Captaines nest.
Some vprore were like that, which lately she did vew.
On which he safety hopes, that earst feard to be lost.
Which when he spyde vpon the earth t'encroch,
Mongst which he found a sword of better say,
With which he forth went into th'open light:
All which do him assayle on euery side,
Which they from many long had robd and rent,
Of which the best he did his loue betake;
And also all those flockes, which they before
With which her winged speed is let and crost,
Which when her father vnderstood, he grew
Which she streight way for dread least, if her syre
For which it loudly cald, and pittifully cryde.
At length a Shepheard, which there by did keepe
Of his first quest, which he had long forlore;
The which the Faery Queene had long afore
The rosie marke, which she remembred well
That litle Infant had, which forth she kest,
The which she bore, the whiles in prison she did dwell.
Which well auizing, streight she gan to cast
Was that same infant, which so long sith past
To saue her chylde, which in misfortunes mouth was plaste.
A little mayde, the which ye chylded tho;
The litle purple rose, which thereon grew,
That yond same is your daughter sure, which yet doth liue.
In which that rose she plainely saw displayd.
Which hauing thought long dead, she fyndes aliue,
Let her by proofe of that, which she hath fylde
For passing ioy, which did all into pitty melt.
In which he many massacres had left,
In which such spoile, such hauocke, and such theft
Through which the Monckes he chaced here & there.
In which what filth and ordure did appeare,
Which spake reprochfully, not caring where nor when.
Or like the hell-borne Hydra, which they faine
To crop his thousand heads, the which still new
With which he drew him forth, euen in his own despight.
And to the other damned ghosts, which dwell
For aye in darkenesse, which day light doth shonne:
With his vile tongue, which many had defamed,
With which some wicked tongues did it backebite,
All in a silken Camus lylly whight,
And to the Dwarfe a while his needlesse spere he gaue.
Deuoure their dam; on whom while so he gazd,
Who all this while with charmes and hidden artes,
He in great passion all this while did dwell,
The wicked witch now seeing all this while
Yet she most faithfull Ladie all this while
But to the virgin comes, who all this while
While flashing beames do daze his feeble eyen,
Her Lordes and Ladies all this while deuise
Returne from whence ye came, and rest a while
Who all that while lay hid in secret shade:
And all the while, most heauenly melody
And all the while Duessa wept full bitterly.
The foolish man, that pitties all this while
And all the while she stood vpon the ground,
With fawning wordes he courted her a while,
Would not a while her forward course pursew,
Who all this while was busie at her beades:
But now a while let downe that haughtie string,
There eke my feeble barke a while may stay,
And all the while salt teares bedeawd the hearers cheaks.
And all the while sweete Musicke did apply
Here she a while may make her safe abode,
Which to attend, a while their forward steps they stay.
Was, (ay the while, that he is not so now)
Yt nought too deare I deemd, while so my dear I sought.
Who all this while were at their wanton rest,
Into her lodging to repaire a while,
Him all that while Occasion did prouoke
But here a while ye may in safety rest,
They stayd a while: and forth she gan proceed:
During the while, that Guyon did abide
A while his heauie eylids couer'd haue,
A while they fled, but soone returnd againe
But Guyon all this while his booke did read,
Do serue their turnes: here I a while must stay,
A while he stood in this astonishment,
And all the while his wounds were dressing, by him stayd.
O turne thy rudder hither-ward a while:
Gazing a while at his vnwonted guise;
And all that while, right ouer him she hong,
So as they gazed after her a while,
And all the while sweet Musicke did diuide
And all the while sweet birdes thereto applide
Therewith a while she her flit fancy fed,
And all the while faire Malecasta bent
To speake a while, ne ready answere make,
Her selfe a while therein she vewd in vaine;
Which all that while she felt to pant and quake,
The cause some say is this: A litle while
They here ariuing, staid a while without,
Tho hauing vewd a while the surges hore,
Who all this while full hardly was assayd
And all the while their malice they did whet
Who al this while lay bleeding out his hart-bloud neare.
He rested him a while, and then the Mayd
Long while he stroue in his courageous brest,
Well may I weene, faire Ladies, all this while
That craue but rowme to rest, while tempest ouerblo'th.
And wearie limbs a while. She nothing quaint
So stared he on her, and stood long while amazed.
But all the while the fisher did securely sleepe.
Had long while laboured it to engraue:
But all the while, that he these speaches spent,
And euery where he might, and euery while
While teares stood in his eies, few drops of bitternesse.
And for her sake her cattell fed a while,
His blindfold eyes he bad a while vnbind,
Then the braue Maid, which all this while was plast,
And all the while he red, she did extend
Vpon the ground a while in slomber lay;
Where lying still a while, both did forget
And round about themselues a while did gaze,
To stay their hands, till he a while had spoken:
In friendly sort, that lasted but a while;
Stood still a while, and his fast footing kept,
And all the while the disentrayled blood
Long while they then continued in that wize,
And all that while, where so they rode or came,
And though some while Fortune from him withdrew,
There lay Sir Scudamour long while expecting,
All that long while vpheld her wrathfull hand,
And feeble hope hung all this while suspence,
Sir Artegall, who all this while was bound
Saue that she algates him a while accompanide.
Vnto the earth, and lay long while in senselesse swowne.
He bowed low, and so a while did lie:
But when a while they had together beene,
And afterwards continu'd there a while,
That all the while he by his side her bore,
Who all the while beheld their wrathfull moode,
Thus they long while continued in fight,
Which all that while I closely had conceld;
And said no more: but I which all that while
Some while he thought, by faire and humble wise
Vnto the place he came within a while,
Who all this while behind him did remaine,
All which when Artegall, who all this while
While she was flying, like a weary weft,
Did stay a while their greedy bickerment,
Proudly stands ouer, and a while doth pause,
And euery while that mighty yron man,
That all that while her life she safely garded:
A while about her with confused eye;
Yet all that while he would not once assay,
Thus there long while continu'd Artegall,
I will a while with his first folly beare,
Thus he long while in thraldome there remayned,
One while she blam'd her selfe; another whyle
A while she walkt, and chauft; a while she threw
A while she walkt, and chauft; a while she threw
That he is not the while in state to woo;
And thereuppon long while stood gazing still,
So thereuppon long while she musing lay,
So there a while they afterwards remained,
Meane while her noble Lord sir Artegall
And left there dead. Meane while the other Knight
But at the sight of these, those were a while debard.
To loose his shield, and long while did contend:
With Belge, who watcht all this while full sad,
There he with Belge did a while remaine,
To which all harkning, did a while asswage
Long while he tug'd and stroue, to get it out,
Of his late fall, a while he rested still:
Ne once to breath a while their angers tempest ceast.
With that his mortall hand a while he stayd,
The wretched man, that all this while did dwell
Whom Calidore a while well hauing vewed,
Meane while his Ladie, which this outrage saw,
And all the while, that same discourteous Knight,
Compelled were themselues a while to rest,
Which way to take: now West he went a while,
And all the while his backe for best safegard,
Where haue ye all this while bin wandring, where bene weft?
I must a while forbeare to you to tell;
And ere that litle while they ridden had,
But if ye please to lend me leaue a while,
Like many water streames, a while she stayd;
His kingdome would continue but a while.
Who all this while stood there beside them bound,
Meane while the Saluage man, when he beheld
And sitting downe, her selfe a while bethought
Who all this while endured for her sake,
Another while I baytes and nets display,
And long while after, whilest him list remaine,
Was by the Captaine all this while defended:
Who all this while at will did range and raine,
There they a while together thus did dwell
Of Calidore; who seeking all this while
The Saluage Knight, that victour was whileare,
The gentle Scudamour, whose hart whileare
Had left in his protection whileare,
Pursuing that proud Knight, the which whileare
Faire Crysogone in slombry traunce whilere:
Whiles sad Night ouer him her ma[n]tle black doth spred
Whiles you in carelesse sleepe are drowned quight.
That here wex old in sleepe, whiles wicked wights
Who whiles he liu'de, was called proud Sans foy,
Whiles none the holy things in safety kept;
He roar'd aloud, whiles life forsooke his stubborne brest.
Whiles old Syluanus slept in shady arber sownd.
Whiles Vna with huge heauinesse opprest,
And trample th'earth, the whiles they may respire;
So they to fight; the whiles the royall Mayd
Whiles he had keeping of his grasing steed,
Whiles thus I heare you of your sorrowes treat.
And whiles he stroue his combred clubbe to quight
Whiles yet his feeble feet for faintnesse reeld,
Whiles he himselfe with greedie great desire
Ah Loue, lay downe thy bow, the whiles I may respire.
Which still wex old in woe, whiles woe still wexeth new.
Whiles euery sence the humour sweet embayd,
Whiles trembling horror did his conscience dant,
Whom still she fed, whiles they were weake & young,
He did receiue, whiles flashing fire about him shone.
Whiles from their iournall labours they did rest,
Whiles some more bold, to measure him nigh stand,
The whiles that hoarie king, with all his traine,
Whiles they his pittifull aduentures heard,
Whiles on her wearie iourney she did ride;
The whiles one sung a song of loue and iollity.
Whiles cursed steele against that badge I bent,
Whiles the sad pang approching she does feele,
Whiles cause not well conceiued ye mistake.
The whiles a losell wandring by the way,
Whiles in the bush he lay, not yet forgot:
For whiles she spake, her great words did apall
The whiles on foot was forced for to yeed,
The whiles to me the treachour did remoue
Whiles they are weake betimes with them contend:
He slips aside; the whiles that furious beast
Whiles Guyon standing by, their vncouth strife does see.
Whiles creeping slomber made him to forget
Whiles through their lids his wanton eies do peepe,
Whiles sad Pyrrochles lies on senselesse ground,
Fights with Cymochles, whiles his bro-
And other whiles vaine toyes she would deuize
Whiles thus she talked, and whiles thus she toyd,
Whiles thus she talked, and whiles thus she toyd,
The whiles with a loue lay she thus him sweetly charm'd.
Whiles nothing enuious nature them forth throwes
Thus to mislead me, whiles I you obaid:
The whiles Cymochles with that wanton mayd
Whiles thus they strugled in that idle waue,
Whiles sad Celeno, sitting on a clift,
Which mortall Princes wore, whiles they on earth did rayne.
The whiles he steru'd with hunger and with drouth
The whiles my hands I washt in puritie,
The whiles my soule was soyld with foule iniquitie.
The whiles the other Ladies mind their merry glee.
Whiles deadly fit thy pupill doth dismay;
At proud Cymochles, whiles his shield was wyde,
The whiles false Archimarge and Atin fled apace.
Whiles it is kept in sober gouernment;
From Faery court. So talked they, the whiles
Whiles in the aire their clustring army flies,
The whiles the viandes in the vessell boyld
The whiles, the Faerie knight did entertaine
Held downe her head, the whiles her louely face
Here needes me, whiles the famous auncestries
The whiles with bloud they all the shore did staine,
Who whiles good fortune fauoured her might,
To which whiles absent he his mind did set,
But let them pas, whiles wind and weather right
Whiles his long legs nigh raught vnto the ground;
The whiles the Prince prickt with reprochfull shame,
That whiles he marueild still, did still him paine:
For whiles they fly that Gulfes deuouring iawes,
Whiles the salt brine out of the billowes sprong.
Whiles the dred daunger does behind remaine.
The whiles sweet Zephirus lowd whisteled
Whiles th'one did row, and th'other stifly steare;
The whiles the nimble boate so well her sped,
The whiles their snowy limbes, as through a vele,
The whiles some one did chaunt this louely lay;
So held them vnder fast, the whiles the rest
The whiles faire Britomart, whose constant mind,
Whiles fruitfull Ceres, and Lyï¿½us fat
But feed on shadowes, whiles I die for food,
And like a shadow wexe, whiles with entire
Whiles yet in infant cradle he did crall;
Whiles thus thy Britons do in languour pine,
The whiles that loue it steres, and fortune rowes;
I read thee soone retyre, whiles thou hast might,
Whiles th'altars fume with frankincense arownd,
Whiles thus he lay in deadly stonishment,
Whiles all her sisters did for her lament,
Whiles on his broad round backe they softly slid
Whiles they the corse into her wagon reare,
The whiles the Nymphes sit all about him round,
For whiles his Lord pursewd that noble Mayd,
Farre in the woods, whiles that he lay in swownd,
Whiles dayly plaisters to his wound she layd,
The whiles her matchlesse beautie him dismayd.
To sleepe, the whiles a gentle slombring swowne
Whiles all her Nymphes did like a girlond her enclose.
The whiles the ioyous birdes make their pastime
The whiles his nets were drying on the sand:
Whiles in their mothers wombe enclosd they were,
The whiles the pitteous Ladie vp did ryse,
Whiles the cold ysickles from his rough beard,
Whiles of a wanton Lady I do write,
Whiles thus we suffer this same dotard old,
Whiles yet on Ida he a shepheard hight,
The whiles vnwares away her wondring eye,
The whiles her husband ranne with sory haste,
The whiles the Boaster from his loftie sell
The whiles their Gotes vpon the brouzes fed,
To shrowd themselues, whiles sleepe their senses did inuade.
The whiles the Championesse now entred has
The whiles her foolish garde, that little knew
Whiles the proud Bird ruffing his fethers wyde,
Whiles thus on earth great Ioue these pageaunts playd,
And take me for their Ioue, whiles Ioue to earth is gone.
Whiles that from heauen he suffered exile.
The whiles the passing brightnes her fraile sences dazed.
The whiles a most delitious harmony,
The whiles the maskers marched forth in trim aray.
For other whiles to her she purpos made
The whiles his loue away the other bore,
Sad Clotho held the rocke, the whiles the thrid
The whiles shril trompets & loud clarions sweetly playd.
Whiles neither lets the other touch the soyle,
The whiles were enterchaunged twixt them two;
Whiles thus they communed, lo farre away
Whiles vnawares his saddle he forwent,
Whiles with long fight on foot he breathlesse was,
The whiles faire Amoret, of nought affeard,
Who lay the whiles in swoune, full sadly set,
The whiles his babling tongue did yet blaspheme
The whiles his life ran foorth in bloudie streame,
The whiles I him condemne, and deeme his paine,
Whiles through the world she walked in this sort,
Could swim like to a fish, whiles he his backe bestrad.
With whom whiles he did in the wood remaine,
The whiles his guilefull groome was fled away:
Whiles Talus watched at the dore all night.
Burnisht with bloudie rust, whiles on the greene
That they the whiles may take lesse heedie keepe,
The whiles the Prince there kept the entrance still:
The whiles the Prince hard preased in betweene,
Whiles she alone is left, and thou here found?
Vpon his steede, whiles she no whit gainesayd,
The whiles the cursed felon high did reare
And whiles he combred was therewith so sore,
Againe whiles he him saw so ill bested,
That in short space, whiles there with her he stayd,
And whiles he her pursued euery where,
Thus whiles they spake, they heard a ruefull shrieke
Whiles yet his foe lay fast in sencelesse sound,
Whiles he him selfe all night did nought but weepe,
Him heedlesse bit, the whiles he was thereof secure.
The whiles the saluage man did take his steede,
The whiles that mighty man did her demeane
The whiles the beast doth rage and loudly rore,
So did the Squire, the whiles the Carle did fret,
And other whiles with bitter mockes and mowes
The whiles that other villaine went about
The whiles the foole did him reuile and flout,
The whiles their flockes in shadowes shrouded bee,
The whiles his Pastorell is led,
And makes huge hauocke, whiles the candlelight
The whiles faire Pastorell through great affright
The which she bore, the whiles in prison she did dwell.
Yet wisedome warnes, whilest foot is in the gate,
And whilest him fortune fauourd, faire did thriue
Whilest here thy shield is hangd for victors hyre,
Whilest Satyrane him from pursuit did let:
Whose parents deare, whilest equall destinies
Whilest she her selfe thus busily did frame,
Whilest with delight of that he wisely spake,
Auauntage, whilest his foe did rage most rife;
Whilest each of Brutus boasted to be borne,
Whilest Romanes dayly did the weake subdew:
Whilest others did them selues embay in liquid ioyes.
Gather therefore the Rose, whilest yet is prime,
Gather the Rose of love, whilest yet is time,
Whilest louing thou mayst loued be with equall crime.
But let vs hence depart, whilest wether serues and wind.
And whilest he bath'd, with her two crafty spyes,
That whilest his breath did strength to him supply,
It fortuned, whilest thus she stifly stroue,
Thus whilest all things in troublous vprore were,
Whilest deadly torments do her chast brest rend,
Where let them wend at will, whilest here I doe respire.
Amidst the bridale feast, whilest euery man
Whilest both you here with many a cursed oth,
To win a willow bough, whilest other weares the bayes.
That none durst euer whilest thou wast aliue,
Yet whilest they liued none did euer see
Where fast infixed, whilest he sought by slight
Whilest through their rifts the ruddie bloud did showre
Thus whilest their minds were doubtfully distraught,
Whilest trembling horrour did his sense assayle,
Whilest he in armes her bore; but when she felt
Whilest he on him was greedy to be wroke,
Whilest thus in battell they embusied were,
His mighty limbs, whilest all with filthy bloud
Whilest I through paines and perlous ieopardie,
The whilest their eldest brother was away,
Whilest thus I spake, behold with happy eye
Whilest here on earth she liued mortallie.
Whilest he reformed that vnciuill fo:
Whilest he to gathering of the gold did fall.
Whilest thus they busied were bout Florimell,
Whilest thus amidst the billowes beating of her
For that Osyris, whilest he liued here,
Where whilest her earthly parts with soft delight
Whilest Fortune fauourd her successe in fight,
To which whilest she lent her intentiue mind,
Who whilest in hand it gryping hard he hent,
There whilest they entring, th'one did th'other stay,
The whilest at him so dreadfully he driue,
Whilest still she stands as stonisht and forlorne:
That it could not be shut, whilest Calidore
Whilest they together for the quarrey stroue,
Saues Serena, whilest Calepine
Of which whilest they discoursed both together,
Thus whilest he was in this distressed case,
Bout which whilest he was busied thus hard,
That with the noise, whilest he did loudly rore,
And beat them back, whilest many vnderneath him fell.
There whilest he thus was setling things aboue,
Whilest she did weepe, of no man mercifide.
Through her dispiteous pride, whilest loue lackt place,
Came running in, and whilest on ground he lay,
There whilest in Morpheus bosome safe she lay,
And long while after, whilest him list remaine,
Whilest Calidore does follow that faire Mayd,
Whilest his faire Pastorella was elsewhere,
The whilest the rest them round about did hemme,
He pypt apace, whilest they him daunst about.
Or how those theeues, whilest one sought her to hold,
Whilest ye in durance dwelt, ye to me gaue
Did cast to ground, whilest none was them to rew;
Whilest Calidore him vnder him downe threw;
And Mulla mine, whose waues I whilom taught to weep.
Lo I the man, whose Muse whilome did maske,
Whilome doth rancle in my riuen brest,
He nought forgot, how he whilome had sworne,
Whose liues, it seemed, whilome there were shed,
Whereof king Nine whilome built Babell towre;
Of which Caduceus whilome was made,
As whilome was the antique worldes guize,
Sith him whilome in Britaine she did vew,
On a faire Ladie Nonne, that whilome hight
And whilome by false Faries stolne away,
That whilome wont in women to appeare?
In Paradize whilome did plant this flowre,
Whilome begot, being but halfe twin of that berth.
Though whilome far much greater then thy fame,
And stately towres of Ilion whilome
Who had forgot, that whilome I heard tell
And cruell battels, which he whilome fought
Which were whilome captiued in their dayes
And left him now as sad, as whilome iollie,
He that from Braggadocchio whilome reft
